prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. So the situation is that the author and their girlfriend live together, and he pays all the bills. She works part-time, and he never minded before until she had to pay for takeout that cost about $40. He's upset about her reaction and wants her to start contributing more.

First, I need to consider the expectations in a relationship. Financial responsibilities can be a sensitive topic. The author mentions he pays everything, which might have been an unspoken agreement. But now he's upset because of her reaction to paying for a small expense. The key points here are communication, fairness, and mutual respect.

The author's girlfriend works part-time, which might mean her income is lower. Even if she's not paying bills, contributing in other ways (like chores, emotional support, etc.) might be part of the balance. The author is now questioning her contribution after one incident. But is it fair to make her start paying bills over a single event?

Also, the author's tone seems a bit harsh when he says "It was some fucking take out." That might indicate he's overreacting. The girlfriend's reaction could be due to feeling suddenly responsible, which might not have been discussed before. The author's decision to make her pay without prior conversation might have caught her off guard.

In relationships, it's important to communicate financial expectations clearly. If the author wanted her to contribute, they should have talked about it before this incident. Now, using this one event to demand she start paying bills might be unfair, especially since she might not be able to afford it. The author is assuming she can contribute more, but without knowing her financial situation beyond her part-time job.

There's also the aspect of respect. The author mentions her attitude was "ugly" and "put out," which suggests a possible lack of understanding from both sides. The author might be projecting his own frustration onto her. Instead of making her pay everything, a more balanced approach would be to discuss how to share expenses based on their incomes.

So, considering all this, the author might be in the wrong because he didn't communicate his expectations beforehand and is now holding a minor incident to a larger issue. The right approach would be to talk with her about splitting costs fairly rather than making her pay over a single $40 instance.
